wikipedia_page.main: Alexander John Melrose (18 March 1889 – 6 September 1962) was a politician in the State of South Australia.

link_mentions.page: Mintaro, South Australia
response: Sir Samuel Way, the  Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of South Australia purchased the property in 1881. In following decades, Kadlunga Station became a famed sheep and horse stud. The first registered Percheron horses to arrive in Australia, in 1915, were sent to Kadlunga.History of the Breed . Percheron Horse Breeders of Australia Inc. Retrieved 15 January 2018. The property was successively owned by some prominent South Australians including John Chewings, Sir Samuel Way and Alexander Melrose. The Gosse family (descendants of Melrose) owned the property for over 100 years before selling the estate in 2017.

The original 1857 house was virtually rebuilt during the 1919-20 alterations for Alexander Melrose. The existing bluestone was rendered during the extensions to match the colour of the new walls of locally quarried, roughly squared random-coursed sandstone, with brick quoins and surrounds to openings. The house now consists of fifteen rooms and all interior fittings date from the 1919-20 alterations. The verandah enclosed the two-storeyed section and the laundry and kitchen in the single-storey wing to the north, while the balcony almost encircles the first floor of the main body of the house.Department of the Environment and Energy. Australian Heritage Database. Search result for Kadlunga. Retrieved 15 January 2018. Extensive farm dry stone walls were built by Italian prisoners of war during World War II.South Australia shows off some stone walls . The Flag Stone; Issue No 35, January 2016. Retrieved 22 January 2018.

| Alexander Melrose (1889–1962) || Owned and resided at Kadlunga where he bred sheep, cattle and horses. Represented the Liberal Party in the House of Assembly seats of Burra Burra and Stanley. || Approaching Elections (20 January 1933). Trove: Northern Argus, page 3. Retrieved 2018-01-14.

response: : LCL MLC Alexander Melrose died on 6 September 1962. Les Hart was elected to fill the vacancy on 20 October.

link_mentions.page: Alexander John Melrose
Samuel Dennison
response: Electoral reform taking effect from the 1938 election saw the abolition of multi-member electorates in the House of Assembly and a return to the single-member system. By January 1937, Dennison had decided to contest the new Stanley electorate, which was also sought by LCL party president and fellow MHA Alexander Melrose. However, by June that year, media reports stated that he had "no chance" of winning preselection and would instead run as an independent. He recontested in Stanley as an independent and lost his seat to Melrose.

link_mentions.page: Candidates of the 1938 South Australian state election
Candidates of the 1941 South Australian state election
response: The seat of Glenelg had remained vacant following the death of incumbent independent MHA William Fisk on 18 December 1940. Stanley Liberal MHA Alexander Melrose switched houses at the election, being elected unopposed for Midland Province.
